title: Logic Architect: Course Overview
introText: FROM ELECTRONS TO COMPUTATION: This course takes you on an epic journey through digital electronics. You'll start with a simple wire and end by building a CPU. Each level teaches real physics and engineering - the same knowledge used to design the chips in your phone and computer.

conceptCards.definition: This course progresses from physics (electrons, voltage) through abstraction layers (gates, circuits, systems) to a working computer.
conceptCards.why: Understanding each layer deeply prepares you for the next. Skipping ahead leads to gaps in understanding.
conceptCards.analogy: Like building a house: foundation (physics), framing (gates), rooms (circuits), complete home (computer).

conceptCards.definition: Each level hides lower-level complexity. Gates hide transistors. Circuits hide gates. CPUs hide circuits.
conceptCards.why: Abstraction makes complex systems manageable. You do not think about electrons when coding.
conceptCards.analogy: Like driving a car: you use the steering wheel abstraction, not individual tire rotations.

conceptCards.definition: Digital uses discrete values (0 and 1). Analog uses continuous values. Digital is noise-resistant.
conceptCards.why: Digital circuits can regenerate signals (a slightly-off 1 becomes a perfect 1), enabling reliable computation.
conceptCards.analogy: Digital is like Morse code (dots and dashes), analog is like speaking (infinite variations).

conceptCards.definition: NAND gates alone can build ANY digital circuit. This simplifies manufacturing enormously.
conceptCards.why: Instead of making 10 different gate types, factories make trillions of identical NAND gates.
conceptCards.analogy: Like having one type of LEGO brick that can build any structure when combined properly.

formulaCards.name: Moore's Law
formulaCards.meaning: Transistor density doubles approximately every 2 years. This exponential growth enabled modern computing.

example.answer: approximately 100+ billion transistors (Apple M2 has 20B, high-end GPUs have 80B+)

exercises.question: If you complete one level per day, how long will this course take?
exercises.hint: Count the main levels: 01-19 plus boss
exercises.answer: 20 days (or faster if you do multiple levels per session!)

exercises.question: Which tier represents the biggest conceptual jump?
exercises.hint: When do we first introduce time and memory into circuits?
exercises.answer: Tier 4 (Sequential Logic) - moving from stateless to stateful circuits is the hardest concept.

realWorld.context: Every electronic device you use - phone, computer, car, appliances - contains the circuits you will learn to build.
realWorld.example: Your smartphone has more computing power than all of NASA had during the Apollo missions - thanks to the miniaturization and integration of these fundamental circuits.
realWorld.numbers: A modern CPU executes approximately 100 billion operations per second. Each operation uses the gates you will learn: AND, OR, XOR, flip-flops, adders.
realWorld.connection: By the end of this course, the magic of computers will be replaced by understanding. You will see circuits, not mysteries.

courseOverview.prerequisites: None - we start from absolute basics
learningOutcomes: Build memory elements and sequential circuits
Implement a working arithmetic logic unit

tierOverview.name: The Silicon Age
tierOverview.description: Learn the physical foundation: how electrons flow, how transistors switch, and how basic gates emerge from physics.
tierOverview.difficultyRamp: GENTLE - These levels are tutorials. Just connect components and observe. No complex design required.
tierOverview.keyInsight: A transistor is just a switch. All computing reduces to switching.

tierOverview.name: Boolean Algebra
tierOverview.description: Discover that NAND alone can build ANY logic function. Master XOR and De Morgan's laws.
tierOverview.difficultyRamp: MODERATE - Start designing small circuits. Level 09 requires combining 3 gates.
tierOverview.keyInsight: NAND is universal. With one gate type, you can build any computer.

tierOverview.name: Combinational Logic
tierOverview.description: Build the circuits that make decisions (MUX), select addresses (decoder), and do math (adders).
tierOverview.difficultyRamp: CHALLENGING - Multi-gate designs. Full adder needs 5 gates working together.
tierOverview.keyInsight: Computers do math with XOR and AND. Addition is the foundation of all arithmetic.

tierOverview.name: Sequential Logic
tierOverview.description: Introduce TIME. Build circuits that remember (latches) and synchronize (flip-flops).
tierOverview.difficultyRamp: CONCEPTUAL LEAP - Understanding feedback and clocking is the hardest conceptual jump.
tierOverview.keyInsight: Feedback creates memory. Clocks create order. Together they enable computation over time.

tierOverview.name: Finite State Machines
tierOverview.description: Design circuits that move through defined states - the control logic inside every processor.
tierOverview.difficultyRamp: DESIGN INTENSIVE - You must plan state transitions before building.
tierOverview.keyInsight: Any sequential behavior can be modeled as states plus transitions.

tierOverview.name: Computer Architecture
tierOverview.description: The grand finale. Build an ALU, then combine everything into a working processor.
tierOverview.difficultyRamp: MASTERY - Integrate all previous knowledge. The boss level is the ultimate test.
tierOverview.keyInsight: A CPU is just gates plus memory plus control. You now understand how computers work.

level_01.title: The Simple Wire
level_01.insight: Electrons drift slowly, but signals travel at near light-speed.

level_02.title: The Transistor
level_02.task: Use a transistor as a controlled switch
level_02.insight: A small signal controls a large current - the basis of amplification.

level_03.title: NOT Gate (Inverter)
level_03.insight: Inversion is the simplest computation - flip 0 to 1.

level_04.title: AND Gate
level_04.task: Output 1 only when both inputs are 1
level_04.insight: Series equals AND. Both switches must close for current to flow.

level_05.title: OR Gate
level_05.insight: Parallel equals OR. Any path conducts.

level_06.title: NAND: The Universal
level_06.insight: NAND equals NOT(AND). It is the only gate type needed to build any circuit.

level_07.title: Logic from NAND
level_07.insight: NAND(A,A) equals NOT(A). Tie the inputs together!

level_08.title: XOR (Exclusive OR)
level_08.insight: XOR is addition without carry. It is the heart of error detection.

level_09.title: De Morgan Laws
level_09.task: Build OR using only NAND gates
level_09.insight: Invert inputs, change AND to OR. This completes the universality proof.

level_10.title: Multiplexer (MUX)
level_10.task: Select between two inputs based on selector
level_10.insight: MUX equals programmable routing. FPGAs use MUX-based lookup tables.

level_11.title: Decoder (2-to-4)
level_11.insight: Every memory access uses decoders to select cells.

level_12.title: Half Adder
level_12.task: Add two bits, output Sum and Carry
level_12.insight: Sum equals XOR, Carry equals AND. This is how computers add!

level_13.title: Full Adder
level_13.insight: Chain full adders for multi-bit arithmetic.

level_14.title: SR Latch
level_14.task: Store and recall a bit using Set/Reset
level_14.insight: Feedback creates memory! Two stable states equals 1 bit of storage.

level_15.title: D Flip-Flop
level_15.task: Capture D input only on clock edge
level_15.insight: All changes happen at the clock edge. This makes design predictable.

level_16.title: Toggle Flip-Flop
level_16.task: Toggle output on each clock pulse
level_16.insight: T-FF divides frequency by 2. Chain them for counters.

level_17.title: 2-Bit Counter
level_17.insight: A counter is the simplest FSM. Every CPU has a program counter.

level_18.title: Traffic Light Controller
level_18.insight: Any sequential behavior equals states plus transitions.

level_19.title: Arithmetic Logic Unit
level_19.task: Add OR subtract based on operation code
level_19.insight: The ALU is where computation happens. Flags enable conditionals.

level_boss.title: The CPU Datapath
level_boss.task: Fetch, decode, and execute an instruction
level_boss.insight: A CPU is gates plus memory plus control. You now understand computers!

phase1_tutorials.description: Pure observation and single connections. Just follow instructions.
phase1_tutorials.tip: Do not worry about solving anything. These levels teach concepts.

phase2_singleGate.description: Use one gate. Understand input to output relationships.
phase2_singleGate.tip: Study the truth table. Match your circuit output to it.

phase3_multiGate.tip: Draw the circuit on paper first. Then implement.

phase4_systems.tip: Break the problem into sub-problems. Build and test incrementally.

phase5_sequential.description: MAJOR CONCEPT SHIFT. Understand feedback and time.
phase5_sequential.tip: Focus on understanding the why before the how. Re-read explanations.

phase6_stateMachines.description: Design state transition logic. Plan states first.
phase6_stateMachines.tip: Draw the state diagram. Label transitions. Then derive equations.

phase7_architecture.description: Integration of all skills. The ultimate challenge.
phase7_architecture.tip: This is where everything comes together. Take your time.
